Award.AwardTitle: Understanding the temperature dependence of consumer-resource interactions
Award.AbstractNarration: Changes in environmental temperature can strongly impact consumer-resource interactions such as those between predators and their prey. These interactions form the basic building blocks of biodiversity and drive the flux of nutrients and materials through ecosystems. A three-pronged approach that combines computation and informatics, mechanistic theory, and laboratory experiments will be used to advance scientific understanding of these processes. For the informatics prong, a comprehensive database has been compiled (203 traits and 403 species measured over a total range of 66Â° C) and will be analyzed to investigate effects of temperature on functional traits such as body velocity and encounter rate. Based on the results, the second prong is to develop a mechanistic model that uses physiological and ecological principles to incorporate temperature effects on population growth rate, mortality rate, and consumption rate. This model will yield predictions for how temperature affects population abundances, species coexistence, and species invasions for diverse taxa in a variety of habitats. The third prong will be to test the full suite of predictions for temperature responses using a system in which all traits can be measured simultaneously. This system is tri-trophic - bladderpod plant, harlequin bug, and two parasitoids - and its life history traits and population dynamics are extensively measured and well understood. Testing predictions within this system will enable model refinement and the inclusion of behavioral aspects, such as search efficiencies of the two parasitoid species in locating host eggs. This work will be used to quantify to what extent entire systems can be described by each of their constituent consumer-resource pairs. Thus, the findings will inform how the effects of temperature on single consumer-resource pairs can be scaled up to study food webs. Together, this research will help to illuminate how fluctuations in temperature can affect parasitoid enemies, a crucial issue in biological pest control. Moreover, this research program will help to elucidate mechanisms for how temperature impacts biodiversity, corresponding to the potential loss of goods, food, and drugs that are critical to humans. Given the evidence for global warming, understanding the effects of temperature on ecosystem dynamics is a particularly pressing problem.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We made substantial progress on our grant’s goals—to better understand and predict how consumer-resource interactions respond to temperature change due to seasonal variation and climate change. We accomplished this by developing and using large databases, mathematical models, and video-tracking experiments. Over the past four years, we published results in top journals: Nature, Proceedings of the National Academy of Science (PNAS) USA, Trends in Ecology and Evolution (TREE), The American Naturalist, Ecology Letters, Ecology, and Journal of Animal Ecology. Through these publications and numerous national and international talks at scientific conferences or as part of public outreach, we disseminated our new databases, new mathematical models, new scientific findings and hypotheses, and computer code. This grant also helped to train high school students, undergraduates, and postdoctoral researchers in important job skills such as data analysis, computer programming, critical thinking, problem solving, and presentation and writing techniques. The primary investigators mentored all members of this team, who in turn made critical contributions to the project.

We completed one of the major goals of this project by compiling, constructing, and analyzing the largest database (named Biotraits) in existence for temperature responses of biological and ecological traits. Temperature responses are data for traits, such as consumption rate, search rate, body velocity, handling time, and abundances, measured at several different temperatures. By plotting and analyzing these data, temperature response curves can be constructed and characterized mathematically to describe how species performance changes with temperature. We created a public website (biotraits.ucla.edu) so that anyone can search and analyze the Biotraits database as it continues to grow and evolve.

In addition, we completed another major goal by designing and constructing an experimental system for taking high-resolution videos of consumer-resource interactions and extracting data from the videos using video-tracking software. This represents the first video-tracking system for studying consumer-resource interactions and is now being used in other labs. Data for consumption rate, body velocity, handling time, attack rate, and attack success were collected. We wrote computer code to analyze the data and understand the movement and handling patterns during consumer-resource interactions. Our video-tracking system will enable the study of questions about consumer-resource interactions, in general, and their response to temperature, specifically.

We made several theoretical advances that were grounded in empirical data. First, we deconstructed the thermal dependence of fitness into the thermal dependence of its component traits: fecundity, mortality, and developmental rate. We discovered that developmental rate often has the largest effect, and we explored how temperate, mediterranean, and tropical species may mediate tradeoffs in the thermal response of different components traits.

Next, by performing a meta-analysis of Biotraits, we showed there is significant variation in the rate of response to temperature change. Predictions for climate change have mainly focused on average responses, but we suggest these predictions will be improved by building models that use full details of the distribution of thermal response rates. Our findings hold across many different taxa, habitats, and biological traits. We further proposed the thermal life-dinner principle.
